Controlling error when testing many hypotheses

In a hypothesis test, we compute some test statistic that is designed to distinguish between a null and alternative hypothesis.  We then compute the probability p(T) of observing a test statistic as large or more extreme as T under the null hypothesis, and reject the null hypothesis if the p-value p(T) is sufficiently small. Propagation of error

Propagation of error describes how uncertainty in estimates propagates forward when we consider functions of those estimates. Suppose I have height and weight measurements for a sample of people.  What is the mean and variance of the BMI?  (BMI is 703 times the weight (in pounds) over the square of the height (in inches).)
